Award.AwardTitle: Peasants' Rights and the United Nations System

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Marc Edelman (Hunter College) will undertake research on new developments in transnational collective action and social movements. The researcher's focus will be recent efforts of agrarian social movements to have the United Nations implement an "International Convention on the Rights of Peasants," similar to earlier successful efforts to implement a UN convention on indigenous people's rights. The draft Peasants' Rights Convention, which was first presented at a Vía Campesina conference in Jakarta in 2002, enumerates a bundle of rights, many of which are already part of existing UN Conventions. Other rights in the draft Convention, however, push existing norms beyond their current bounds, such as claims of a "right to reject" intellectual property of crop genetic material or demands for participation in international economic policymaking processes. The authors of the draft Convention assert that peasants, like native peoples, are a vulnerable group, with culturally specific characteristics and practices that deserve international recognition and protection.

The researcher will collect information on the origins, development, funding, and current activities of the campaign. He also will examine the campaign's impact on the civil society networks of which it is a part and on agenda-setting processes, discourses about rights and development, and public-private partnerships within the UN system. Research methods will include collection and analysis of relevant documents; interviews with key stakeholders; and observation in peasant organization offices, meetings, and public activities. Research venues include UN agencies in New York, Geneva, and Rome; offices of European cooperation agencies that fund or provide logistical support to transnational agrarian movements; and the headquarters of the Vía Campesina transnational agrarian movement in Jakarta.

The project draws on and will contribute to social scientific studies of: (1) collective action and transnational social movements; (2) human rights and rights-claiming processes; and (3) public-private partnerships between global governance institutions and civil society actors. It will provide a window onto transnational processes of development and diffusion of new ideas about rights, in a sector of the world population that is vast and whose new rights claims have not been previously studied.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project analyzed and documented one contemporary case in the long historical expansion of understandings of human rights: the campaign of transnational agrarian social movements to have the United Nations implement a new international instrument—a declaration or a convention—on the rights of peasants (a group that constitutes upwards of one-third of the world population). It examined political contention in international arenas over new legal norms and concepts and the role of grassroots campaigns for new kinds of rights. Field research was carried out in Indonesia, in Germany with right-to-food activists, in Geneva at the United Nations, and in Honduras, where human rights and peasant activists sought to highlight particularly egregious rights violations in order to argue for new rights standards at the international level. Research methods included the collection and analysis of documentary materials, oral historical and key informant interviews with diplomats and civil society activists, attendance at formal sessions and side events at the United Nations, and participant observation in informal strategy meetings of key actors.

The history of the international campaign for a new peasants’ rights instrument begins in Indonesia in the 1990s. Following the fall of the Suharto dictatorship and the return to democracy, peasant activists began to organize to demand rights that had been denied to them during the long decades of authoritarian rule. They elaborated a “peasants’ bill of rights” for Indonesia and began to seek allies abroad in order to campaign for similar rights at the international level. In 2001, an Indonesian peasant leader spoke before the United Nations Human Rights Commission (the predecessor of today’s Human Rights Council) in favor of an international convention on peasants’ rights. In 2007, after native movements secured passage of the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, the peasant activists rewrote their proposed draft instrument to make it more compatible with existing international law and then intensified their lobbying efforts.  In 2010 the Human Rights Council’s Advisory Committee (its “think tank”) issued a preliminary study on the right to food which included as an appendix the activists’ draft. In February 2012 the Advisory Committee issued its “Final Study on Advancement of the Rights of Peasants and Other People Working in Rural Areas,” which contained an appendix with its own declaration on peasants’ rights. In September 2012 the Council approved a resolution creating an Inter-Governmental Working Group to finalize a draft declaration on peasants’ rights. The project’s PI was able to observe and participate in the first session of the new Working Group in Geneva in July 2013.

Understanding the concerns of peasant communities is vital to U.S. efforts to improve relations with developing countries, especially as regards trade, aid and agricultural assistance policies. Similarly, understanding the motivations of organized blocs and of member states with large peasant populations in the United Nations can strengthen our ability to build new alliances and to advance the interests of the United States within the United Nations. This would be of relevance to both the American government and the private sector.
